title: About AMP Quality Energy Services
content: AMP Quality Energy Services (AMP) provides electrical testing, commissioning, maintenance, and calibration services for industrial and mission-critical facilities, including data centers. AMP technicians follow NETA standards and OEM procedures. Offerings include acceptance testing, maintenance testing, engineering studies, infrared (IR) thermography, protective relay testing, primary injection testing, and NIST-traceable calibration through AMP Calibration.

title: AMP Calibration Overview
content: AMP Calibration provides certified, NIST-traceable calibration services for electrical, safety, torque, and live-line tools. We offer fast turnaround, on-site options, detailed certificates, and recall reminders. Certificates include as-found/as-left data, measurement uncertainty, standards used, and environmental conditions when applicable.

title: NETA Accreditation — What It Means
content: NETA-accredited companies are third-party, independent electrical testing firms that meet NETA's quality requirements for processes, equipment, safety, and technician competency. NETA certification focuses on the company and its technicians—not on manufacturers—to ensure unbiased testing and reliable results.

title: Key NETA Standards (High-Level Summary)
content: 1) NETA ATS: Acceptance Testing Specifications — baseline tests and inspections for new or newly installed electrical power equipment and systems prior to energization. 2) NETA MTS: Maintenance Testing Specifications — test intervals, procedures, and criteria to assess equipment condition in service. 3) NETA ECS: Standard for Electrical Commissioning Specifications — integrated commissioning process ensuring systems operate as intended. Use the latest editions and project-specific plans; always defer to OEM instructions and AHJ.

title: SOP: Acceptance Testing – Metal-Enclosed Switchgear
content: Visual & mechanical inspection, Insulation resistance testing, Contact resistance, Primary injection (where applicable), Functional checks of interlocks and controls, Relay settings verification vs. coordination study, Documentation & punch list. Follow latest NETA ATS, OEM instructions, and safety procedures. Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) required.

title: SOP: Maintenance – Protective Relays
content: Review settings vs. latest coordination study, Functional testing (operate & trip), Secondary injection where applicable, Verify CT/PT ratios and polarity, Record as-found/as-left data, Update asset database and label changes. Follow NETA MTS intervals or owner program. Coordinate outages to minimize downtime.

title: SOP: Infrared (IR) Thermography
content: Pre-job briefing and safety plan, Survey energized equipment with load ≥40% where feasible, Capture thermal and visual images, Classify findings by temperature rise & severity, Recommend corrective actions & re-inspection windows. Comply with NFPA 70E approach boundaries. Use calibrated camera; include emissivity and load notes in report.

title: SOP: Medium-Voltage Cable VLF/hipot
content: Insulation resistance pre-check, VLF test per cable type and rating, Monitor leakage current, Partial discharge test if specified, Sheath testing where applicable, Document with pass/fail criteria. Select test levels/durations per standard and cable insulation type. De-energize and properly ground prior to setup.

title: SOP: Transformer Oil Sampling & DGA
content: Warm sampling point when possible, Purge tap to avoid contamination, Label and chain-of-custody, Lab analysis for moisture, acidity, interfacial tension, DGA gases, Trend with previous results, Recommend corrective actions (dry-out, filtration, maintenance). Observe environmental and spill controls; use clean, compatible sample bottles.

title: Electrical Safety (NFPA 70E) – Key Practices
content: Perform Job Safety Planning and Job Briefings. Establish electrically safe work conditions when feasible. Respect shock and arc-flash boundaries, choose appropriate PPE, and use LOTO procedures. Only qualified persons perform testing on energized equipment with documented justification.

title: What Every Test Report Should Include
content: Scope, equipment list with nameplate data, test instruments with calibration dates, procedures and standards used, as-found/as-left measurements, pass/fail criteria, deficiencies with photos, recommendations with severity, and sign-off by qualified reviewer. Provide both PDF and source data if requested.

title: Scheduling Defaults
content: Standard site hours: 7:00–17:00 local unless otherwise specified. Night or weekend work is available per quote. Lead time varies by scope; critical outages and data centers prioritized. Provide site access, escorts, and permits.

title: Quoting Checklist (Estimator Use)
content: One-line diagrams and equipment schedule, Site location(s) and access constraints, Target dates/outage windows and shift requirements, Standards/specs to follow (NETA ATS/MTS/ECS, OEM, AHJ), Test report format, data handoff, and labeling needs, Safety/site orientation and required PPE, Insurance/bonding requirements, Waste handling or environmental controls, Calibration certificates needed in submittal, Deliverables due dates and review meetings

title: Typical SLA Targets
content: Draft reports within 5 business days of demobilization for standard scopes; expedited options available. Calibration certificates delivered within 48–72 hours for standard items; same-day on-site available when feasible.

title: Calibration Scope – Representative Instruments
content: Multimeters, clamp meters, insulation resistance testers, megohmmeters, micro-ohmmeters, primary injection sets (verification), secondary injection sets, torque wrenches/drivers, live-line tools (sticks, testers), and IR cameras (performance checks). Certificates document traceability and uncertainty budgets where applicable.

title: Calibration Pre-Check & RMA Tips
content: Include previous certs if available, list known issues, provide accessories/probes, protect battery-powered units, and remove personal data from instruments with memory. Use sturdy packaging and note required return date.

title: Data Center Commissioning – Essentials
content: Coordinate with CxA and GC. Verify sequence of operations for UPS, switchgear, generators, STS/ATS, and cooling. Perform integrated systems testing (IST) with scripted scenarios, witness testing, and clear pass/fail criteria. Capture timings, waveforms, and alarms; ensure labeling and as-builts match tested configuration.

title: IR Finding Classification – Example Scheme
content: Level 1 (Monitor): ΔT < 10°C above reference; schedule repair. Level 2 (Action): ΔT 10–25°C; plan corrective maintenance soon. Level 3 (Critical): ΔT > 25°C or rapid rise; immediate attention; consider de-energizing.

title: Rubber Insulating Glove Testing – Class 2 Overview
content: Class 2 gloves are typically tested per relevant ASTM standards for visual defects, air testing, and dielectric proof testing. Follow manufacturer care instructions, maintain storage with glove protectors, and observe retest intervals defined by standards and company policy.

title: Why hire a NETA-accredited firm?
content: NETA accreditation assures independent, standards-based testing by qualified technicians with traceable equipment and QA oversight.

title: What does NIST-traceable mean?
content: Measurements are compared through an unbroken chain to national standards maintained by NIST, with documented uncertainties.

title: Can testing be done without powering down?
content: Some inspections (like IR thermography) require energized conditions, but many tests require outages. We plan around your windows.

title: How fast can I get reports?
content: Standard scopes are delivered within 5 business days of demobilization; rush delivery is available by request.

title: What regions do you serve?
content: We mobilize nationwide, with frequent work in the Southeast and data center corridors. International by arrangement.

title: Arc Flash Boundary
content: Distance at which incident energy equals 1.2 cal/cm²; beyond this, second-degree burn risk drops.

title: Coordination Study
content: Engineering study to set protective devices so upstream devices trip after downstream devices.

title: Primary Injection
content: High-current testing through the primary circuit to validate CTs, relays, and bus/joint integrity.

title: Secondary Injection
content: Low-level signal injection directly into relay inputs to validate protection logic and trip outputs.

title: IR Thermography
content: Thermal imaging of energized equipment to detect anomalies like loose terminations or overloads.

title: DGA
content: Dissolved Gas Analysis of transformer oil to identify fault signatures and insulation aging.

title: LOTO
content: Lockout/Tagout—procedures to control hazardous energy during service or maintenance.

title: NFPA 70E
content: Standard for Electrical Safety in the Workplace, addressing electrical safety-related work practices.

title: Job Briefing Outline (Short Form)
content: 1) Scope & tasks 2) Hazards & mitigations 3) Roles & communication 4) Approach boundaries & PPE 5) Energy control/LOTO steps 6) Test instrument verification 7) Emergency plan and contacts 8) Sign-off.

title: Customer Email – Estimate Request (Template)
content:
Subject: Testing & Calibration Scope for [Facility]

Hello [Name],

Please see our attached questionnaire covering equipment lists, outage windows, and deliverables. Once returned, we can turn around pricing quickly. We are a NETA-aligned testing provider with NIST-traceable calibration.

Best regards,
AMP Team

title: Protection & Coordination Study – Required Inputs
content: One-line diagram (latest revision), Utility fault data and transformer parameters, Protective device list (breakers, relays, fuses), Load profiles and critical equipment, Existing settings files and relay models, Arc flash model requirements (if combined)

title: Instrument Control & Traceability
content: Every test instrument is labeled with calibration due date and unique ID. Technicians verify function before/after testing with check sources as applicable and record serials in reports.

title: Mobilization & Site Access Requirements
content: Confirm gate access, escorts, lift/forklift availability, storage space, and laydown areas. Provide hot work permits if required, and coordinate with on-site safety for energized work plans.

title: Test Data Retention Policy (Summary)
content: Store raw data, images, and reports in secure repositories with role-based access. Maintain retention per contract requirements; typical minimum 5–7 years. Provide exports upon written request.

title: Escalation Path – Critical Finding During Testing
content: Stop work if immediate hazard exists. Notify site representative and AMP supervisor. Document condition with photos/measurements. Provide temporary risk controls where safe. Issue a written notice and recommended next steps prior to re-energization.

title: How do you price projects?
content: We price by scope, equipment quantity, outage windows, shift premiums, travel, reporting level, and required standards. Lump-sum or T&M available.

title: Do you offer emergency testing?
content: Yes—24/7 response for outages and critical facilities. We dispatch based on proximity and inventory availability.

title: Do you follow OEM instructions?
content: Yes. OEM procedures and tolerances take precedence where applicable, alongside NETA and AHJ requirements.

title: Can you update labels during testing?
content: Yes, if requested: equipment IDs, arc-flash labels (with current study), and breaker setting labels after approval.

title: Project Intake Questions (Chatbot Prompt)
content: Facility type & location, Scope type (acceptance, maintenance, commissioning, calibration), Equipment list or one-line diagrams available?, Outage windows and dates, Standards required by spec (NETA, NFPA 70E, IEEE, OEM), Deliverables format and deadlines, Special safety or site requirements, Budgetary vs. firm quote needed

title: Recordkeeping – High-Level Summary
content: Maintain auditable records of tests, calibrations, qualifications, and safety training. Ensure traceability of instruments and technician qualifications align with internal procedures and client requirements.

title: Switchgear Acceptance Testing
content: Acceptance testing of MV/LV switchgear, breakers, relays, meters, and controls.

title: Transformer Maintenance Testing
content: Maintenance testing of transformers (insulation resistance, power factor, oil sampling if liquid-filled).

title: Cable Systems Testing
content: VLF/hipot and diagnostic testing of MV cables, terminations, and splices.

title: IR Survey Services
content: Infrared thermography survey of energized equipment with severity-ranked findings.

title: Protective Relay Testing
content: Secondary injection testing and settings verification for protective relays.

title: Example KPIs
content: Report on-time delivery rate, Calibration turnaround time (avg days), Rework rate / NCR count, Safety leading indicators (# JSAs completed), Instrument calibration compliance (%)

title: Breaker Tripping – Generic Troubleshooting Flow
content: 1) Verify load and recent changes 2) Inspect terminations and thermal signs 3) Review protection settings and coordination 4) Perform primary/secondary tests as appropriate 5) Check for mechanical wear or binding 6) Consult OEM for refurbishment limits.

title: Typical Deliverables
content: PDF test report with photos and signatures, Native data exports (CSV or OEM format) upon request, Updated labels and settings sheets, Punch list with priorities and recommended actions, Closeout meeting and lessons learned notes

title: Arc Flash Study Integration with Testing
content: Gather as-found protective settings during testing and reconcile with study models. Update labels after approved changes and provide change logs for owner records.

title: Live-Line Tools – Care & Checks (Summary)
content: Keep clean and dry; store in protective sleeves. Perform visual inspection, wipe-downs, and periodic dielectric tests per applicable standards. Avoid surface contamination and damage that reduces creepage distance.

title: Acceptance vs. Maintenance – Key Differences
content: Acceptance establishes a baseline for new installations, often with higher test levels and 100% device coverage. Maintenance focuses on condition assessment over time with interval-based sampling and trending.

title: Collect Quote Requirements
content: Intent to collect quote requirements with required slots: equipment_list, location, outage_window, standards, deliverables_due_date

title: Project Status Update
content: Intent to update project status with required slots: project_id, site_name, target_date

title: Start Calibration RMA
content: Intent to start calibration RMA with required slots: instrument_type, model, due_date, accessories_included

title: Request Emergency Service
content: Intent to request emergency service with required slots: site_location, issue_description, contact_phone

title: Priority Codes for Findings
content: P1: Critical — immediate risk; address prior to re-energization. P2: High — plan corrective action at earliest safe opportunity. P3: Moderate — schedule maintenance; monitor until resolved. P4: Low — track and address with routine work.

title: Evidence Photo Guidance
content: Capture wide (context) and tight (detail) shots; include nameplates and labels. Use consistent naming tied to equipment IDs. Ensure timestamp sync and retain originals.

title: Change Management in Live Data Centers
content: All testing and settings changes require documented change tickets, MOPs, and back-out plans. Coordinate with operations for redundancy and risk approvals before work.

title: Environmental Controls (Summary)
content: Manage oil handling, spill kits, and waste streams per local regulations. Dispose of test byproducts (e.g., used wipes) appropriately. Maintain SDS access for chemicals used.

title: Spare Parts & OEM Coordination
content: For deficiencies requiring replacement parts, coordinate OEM lead times and approve alternates as needed. Document serial numbers and firmware for traceability.

title: Technician Qualifications (Summary)
content: Field staff maintain training in electrical safety, LOTO, meter safety, and task-specific competencies. Lead technicians demonstrate experience with applicable equipment and test sets; work is reviewed for QA.
